musicalLanguage.description: Stevie Wonder wrote this for his newborn daughter Aisha in 1976. The melody is built on a simple diatonic pattern over a chromatic harmonic bassline — the kind of thing that sounds effortless but is harmonically sophisticated. The harmonica intro is iconic, but on piano the melody sings just as sweetly. The groove is everything.
musicalLanguage.structure: Verse form — two 8-bar passes through the main progression. The first pass states the melody simply, the second adds rhythmic variation and a wider melodic arc. No chorus per se — the verse IS the hook.
keyMoments: Measures 1-2: E major to G#m — the tonic to the relative minor feeling. The melody lands on G#, establishing the vocal range.
Measures 3-4: C#m7 to B7 — the vi to V. Classic R&B turnaround. The melody descends stepwise.
Measures 5-6: A to Am — the IV to iv. The minor IV is the emotional heart — that bittersweet Stevie move.
Measures 7-8: E/B to B7 — resolution over a bass pedal. The melody floats home.
Measure 13: Am chord — the emotional peak of the second pass. Minor IV with the melody at its highest.
teachingGoals: The major-to-minor-IV progression (A to Am) — one of the most powerful moves in pop and R&B. The single chromatic note (C# going to C natural) changes everything.
Left hand shell voicings with a walking bass feel — root movement drives the harmony forward.
Syncopation: the melody sits slightly behind the beat. Don't rush. Let the groove breathe.
Smooth voice leading: the right hand moves in small intervals, connecting chord tones across changes.
The chromatic bass descent (E-D#-C#-B) gives the progression its forward motion.
styleTips: This is a feel song. The groove matters more than the notes. Play it relaxed, slightly behind the beat.
Keep the left hand steady and grounded — it's the heartbeat. The right hand floats on top.
The Am chord (measure 5) should feel like a sigh. Don't hit it hard — let the minor color speak.
Dynamics should be gentle throughout — this is a lullaby at heart. Even the loud moments are warm.
Listen to Stevie's harmonica phrasing — that's what the right hand melody should feel like. Vocal, not mechanical.

measures.teachingNote: E major — home. The melody enters with a pickup on G#, rises to B (the 5th), and settles back. Left hand sets the groove: root-fifth pulse. Keep it steady and relaxed.
G#m — the iii chord. The melody rises F#-G#-B, all chord tones. Left hand shifts to G# bass. The harmony darkens slightly — relative minor territory.
C#m7 — the vi chord. The melody descends stepwise A-G#-F#-E. This is the emotional center of the phrase — every note is a chord tone or passing tone. Left hand: C#-G# root-fifth.
B7 — the V chord. The melody turns upward D#-E-F# (the 3rd, 4th, 5th of B). The dominant wants to resolve. Left hand: B root with F# fifth.
A major — the IV chord. The melody sits on A-G#-A-B, hovering around the root. This is bright and open. Left hand: A-E root-fifth.
Am — the minor IV. THIS is the Stevie Wonder move. The C natural in the bass (instead of C#) turns major to minor. The melody descends A-G#-E. Feel the melancholy — it's a lullaby moment.
E/B — tonic over dominant bass. The melody ornaments downward G#-F#-E, drops to B, then returns. Left hand holds B-E, creating a bass pedal that pulls toward resolution.
B7 resolving to E. The melody F#-G# resolves to E. Left hand B-F# walks down to E (home). The first pass is complete — a full journey through the progression.

measures.rightHand: R:e G#4:e B4:e A4:e G#4:q E4:q
measures.teachingNote: Second pass — E major again, but the melody adds eighth-note motion. G#-B-A-G# ornaments the same shape. More conversational, more alive.
G#m — eighth-note melody weaves F#-G#-A-G# before landing on B. The rhythm is more active but the harmony is the same. This is how R&B builds — same changes, more movement.
C#m7 — the melody reaches up to C#5 (the highest note so far) and descends. Wider arc than the first pass. The emotion is building.
B7 — the melody rises and falls F#-G#-B-A, more motion than before. The dominant chord is restless, pushing forward.
A major — the melody peaks at C#5 again. This is the emotional high point. The IV chord is bright and open, the melody is at its widest.
Am — minor IV again. Same beautiful move. The melody comes down A-G#-E, surrendering to the bittersweet color. This is where the song lives.

measures.rightHand: G#4:e F#4:e E4:e F#4:e G#4:q E4:q
measures.teachingNote: E/B — the melody ornaments with sixteenth-like motion: G#-F#-E-F#-G#-E. More elaborate than the first pass. The groove is in full swing.
Final resolution. B7 to E. The melody lands softly on E with a whole note. Left hand walks B-F#-E. Home. The song could loop forever — that's the beauty of it.
